titleStmt.title: Our Separate Ways
Women and the Black Freedom Movement in Durham, North Carolina

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of North Carolina Press

titleStmt.title: Our Separate Ways
Women and the Black Freedom Movement in Durham, North Carolina

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of North Carolina Press

note.p: In an in-depth community study of women in the civil rights movement, Christina Greene examines how several generations of black and white women, low-income as well as more affluent, shaped the struggle for black freedom in Durham, North Carolina. In the city long known as "the capital of the black middle class," Greene finds that, in fact, low-income African American women were the sustaining force for change.

projectDesc.p: The electronic edition is part of the Long Civil Rights Movement digitization project, a collaboration between UNC-Chapel Hill and the University of North Carolina Press.

editorialDecl.p: The text has been encoded using the recommendations for TEI P5.
Any hyphens occurring in line breaks have been removed, and the trailing part of a word has been joined to the preceding line.
All special characters have been transcribed as Unicode characters, except for the five reserved XML entities.
Indentation in lines has not been preserved.

list.item: African American women--North Carolina--Durham--Political activity--History--20th century.

I Can’t Catch Everybody, but I Can Try Black Power
